options: Speak to your clinical supervisor about your situation
Call in sick for a few days to grieve properly
Carry on working as you are
Schedule a meeting with you educational supervisor and discuss bereavement leave
Ask a colleague to cover for you during your evening shifts so you can leave early
Make an appointment to see your GP to seek help
Self-prescribe some anti-depressants
Try and avoid the stresses of work by sitting in the mess
questions:
You are a F2 doctor working in Intensive Care. You have had a recent family bereavement and are struggling to cope at work. You are finding mundane tasks challenging and are having difficulty concentrating.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This scenario tests awareness of your own physical and mental health. As doctors, we often overlook our own health and it is important to realise when we may be struggling. In this situation, you should approach your clinical supervisor as this is affecting your clinical work (option 1). You may be entitled to bereavement leave which you should discuss with your educational supervisor (option 4). You should also see your GP to seek help (option 6). This shows proactive behaviour and awareness of your own health.

Asking a colleague to cover you so you leave earlier in the evenings is unsafe as you are doubling their workload (option 5). Carrying on as you are may be dangerous as you are risking patient safety (option 3). Self medicating is highly discouraged (option 7). Avoiding work by sitting in the mess does not address the underlying issue (option 8).

questions:
You are an ST1 doctor working on a general medical ward. Upon arriving in the morning you find a variety of situations that need addressing.

Rank the following in order of priority
(1 = Higher priority; 5 = Lower priority)
notes:
A patient with sudden shortness-of-breath may have a potentially life-threatening problem which would require immediate intervention. This is therefore the first priority. The next priority would be to speak with the nurse who is concerned about a patient. Until you speak to her you will not be able to assess the urgency of the problem.

Inserting a cannula prior to coronary angiography would help with patient flow but it is not an urgent matter. There is no indication in the scenario that the consultant is phoning you regarding an urgent matter, although you will not know this until you have spoken to them.

By definition, patients who are going home are well and hence come lower down the list when prioritising tasks.

Ask the consultant to stop the presentation due to the lack of informed consent to share his medical images

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a gastroenterology ward. One of your patients is an elderly man with dementia who presented with haematemesis. He has had a number of investigations on the Acute Medical Unit prior to coming to the ward including bloods and a chest x-ray. In the morning he has an OGD performed in the gastroscopy suite. At lunchtime your consultant presents a video of the endoscopy findings together with his other results during a lunchtime meeting. There are no patient details on the video or other investigation results. A number of doctors and specialist nurses are present at the meeting, including many who are not involved in the care of your patient.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The rapid spread of smartphones, digital cameras and related technology has brought new dilemmas to patient care. In response to this the GMC issued guidelines in 2011 - 'Making and using visual and audio recordings of patients'.

There are however no problems with sharing anonymised patient images in certain situations. The GMC states: Consent to make the recordings listed below will be implicit in the consent given to the investigation or treatment, and does not need to be obtained separately:
  • Images of internal organs or structures
  • Images of pathology slides
  • Laparoscopic and endoscopic images
  • Recordings of organ functions
  • Ultrasound images
  • X-rays

Using medical images as in above scenario is extremely common and a normal part of teaching and patient care. The aim of the question is too tease out a combination of common sense, real-life hospital experience and knowledge of GMC guidance.

As there are no problems with using such images the best response is to do nothing (E). If you're ever not sure then speaking directly to the person involved (A) is the best next step. If you don't feel able to do this then speaking to the registrar (C) is an alternative option. It is better (especially for you!) to speak to your colleagues in private (A & C) rather than halt a meeting in front of everyone (B). Involving a patient's relatives in your misunderstanding is likely to make them anxious about the quality of care their loved one is receiving (D).

options: Ask your immediate senior to hold the bleep whilst you speak to the relatives
Leave it in a safe place until you've finished talking to the relatives
Keep hold of the bleep and answer calls if they come
Keep hold of the bleep and but just make a note of the numbers to contact until after speaking to the relatives

questions:
You are a junior doctor on a regular day shift. An elderly patient who was admitted with pneumonia has died suddenly. The family are not yet aware and the nurses bleep you to come and chat to the family when they arrive. Due to the unexpected nature of the death, you estimate you may be chatting with them for 20 minutes.

What is the most appropriate thing to do with your bleep whilst speaking to the family? Rank in order the following actions
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario describes a situation where you are about to break bad news to a family. Having a bleep going off in the middle of the discussion may be distressing to the relatives and is hence best avoided. The best response is therefore to give your bleep to your senior in the same team. They are best placed to answer and triage any calls. The next best option would be to leave it with a nurse on your ward who can interrupt you if there is an emergency.

From a patient safety aspect, it's important that there isn't undue delay in answering bleeps. Therefore if you do take the bleep with you it is better to answer them rather than simply take down numbers.

Leaving it at the nurses' station is a poor response as you risk not being quickly contactable in the event of an emergency.

options: Tell the HCA to forget the incident to avoid getting the student in trouble
Copy the images to the secure hospital drive so they are at least stored safely
Ask the student to stop immediately, ensure no further images are taken, and follow local information-governance steps to secure and arrange deletion of any images
Tell the student he must now get formal consent in writing from Mr Singh for the use of the images
Call security to confiscate the student’s phone
Post in the staff WhatsApp group asking if anyone else saw the photos
Inform Mr Singh of what happened, apologise sincerely, explain the steps being taken and answer questions
Make a contemporaneous, objective note in the clinical record about the incident, your discussion with Mr Singh and the plan
Advise the student to blur the face and keep the images for educational use
Escalate to the supervising consultant and the nurse in charge; follow the local information governance policy (and medical school lead) for formal management
questions:
t’s 17:45 on the surgical ward. An HCA tells you that a keen medical student has been taking photos on their personal phone of Mr Amar Singh’s stage 3 sacral pressure ulcer “for their portfolio.”

Mr Singh has not given consent to photography and is unaware images were taken. The student admits it, says they “meant well,” and plans to upload the photos later for educational purposes. Mr Singh is stable and comfortable.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Ask the student to stop immediately, ensure no further images are taken, and follow local information-governance steps to secure and arrange deletion of any images is most appropriate. Your first duty is to protect the patient and prevent further harm. GMC guidance on confidentiality and data protection requires prompt action to stop unsafe practice. Involve the ward manager/IG team for proper deletion/containment; don’t handle the device yourself, but do verify that the risk is contained (eg. student steps away from clinical area and that the images not shared or uploaded).

Inform Mr Singh of what happened, apologise sincerely, explain the steps being taken and answer questions is most appropriate. This is the professional duty of candour: tell patients promptly when a notifiable incident has occurred, provide a genuine apology, explain what will be done to put it right, and how recurrence will be prevented. Use clear, compassionate language and check understanding.

Escalate to the supervising consultant and the nurse in charge; follow the local information governance policy (and medical school lead) for formal management is most appropriate. You must seek senior help for incidents involving confidentiality breaches. Seniors and IG can coordinate secure deletion, assess impact, and manage training/disciplinary steps. This aligns with GMC expectations to raise concerns and work within your competence.

The remaining options are inappropriate/less appropriate:

Tell the HCA to forget the incident to avoid getting the student in trouble is inappropriate. Concealing an incident breaches honesty and obstructs learning and prevention. GMC expects openness and raising concerns when patient confidentiality is compromised.

Copy the images to the secure hospital drive so they are at least stored safely is inappropriate. Creating or transferring unauthorised patient images extends the breach. Without explicit consent and governance approval, this further violates confidentiality and data protection principles.

Tell the student he must now get formal consent in writing from Mr Singh for the use of the images is inappropriate. Consent must be informed and prospective; seeking it after covert photography is coercive and invalid. Focus on candour, containment, and proper reporting.

Call security to confiscate the student’s phone is inappropriate and disproportionate. Unless there is an immediate criminal concern or risk of absconding with sensitive data despite containment efforts, confiscation is disproportionate and may create legal/consent issues. Use formal information governance channels instead.

Post in the staff WhatsApp group asking if anyone else saw the photos is inappropriate. Broadcasting details on informal platforms risks further confidentiality breaches. Use official reporting/escalation pathways.

Make a contemporaneous, objective note in the clinical record about the incident, your discussion with Mr Singh and the plan is inappropriate at this time. Accurate documentation and organisational reporting support transparency and learning (organisational duty of candour). It’s essential, but follows immediate containment, disclosure, and escalation of the situation. Therefore, it is not appropriate at this stage.

Advise the student to blur the face and keep the images for educational use is inappropriate. Even de-identified images require appropriate consent and governance. The photos were taken without consent on a personal device; they must not be retained or used.

title: Duty of candour
body:
All healthcare professionals must be honest when something has gone wrong. They must:
  • Tell the patient when something has gone wrong
  • Apologise to the patient (or carer or family member where appropriate)
  • Offer an appropriate resolution
  • Explain the potential short and long-term effects of the error

Important to note:
  • Saying sorry is not an admission of legal liability
  • The patient has a right to receive an apology from 'the most appropriate team member' - this will usually be the lead or accountable clinician
  • The process for reporting adverse incidents and near misses varies between different health organisations: you must follow your own organisations policy
  • The National Report d scheme

options: Immediately go and review the patient in case they are unwell
Find out more clinical details including basic observations and tell them you will come as soon as you can safely leave your patient
Explain you are currently reviewing a patient who is acutely unwell and tell them you will come as soon as you can safely leave your patient
Find out more clinical details including basic observations and bleep your registrar if you cannot safely leave your patient
Ask the nurse to get one of his colleagues to review the patient and bleep you if still necessary
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in an acute hospital. You are aware that one of the nursing staff is known to often bleep doctors requesting a review of patient he feels are unwell, yet on review they appear medically stable. This nurse bleeps you during a night-shift, whilst you are busy clerking in a patient who has presented with a NSTEMI, asking for a medical review on another patient of yours who 'just doesn't look right'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
After working in a hospital for a while you may become aware that some staff have a reputation for being very good, where as others may be on the other end of the spectrum. It is of course though important to act in a professional way at all times and always put the interests of patients first.

In this scenario you have responsibilities to two patients, the patient you are with who has been admitted with a NSTEMI and the patient you've been bleeped about who may, or may not, be unwell.

The first priority is therefore to gather more information including vital signs which could help you gauge the urgency of review. If you cannot safely leave your current patient and the ward patient requires urgent review then you should contact your senior for support (option D).

The next best option is B. Here you are again finding out basic information to help prioritisation. However, you are not utilising your team to help safely manage patients as with option D.

Option C is worse as you are not finding out basic triage information although you are at least reassuring the ward staff that you will review the patient as soon as you can. Even if the ward patient's observations are normal it would be wrong to ignore a fellow professional who is concerned about the patient, even if he appears to have a 'reputation'.

Asking the nurse to get one of his colleagues to review the patient is obviously going to antagonise the nurse (option E) and is unlikely to result in a different outcome.

Leaving a patient who is acutely unwell (option A) is the worst option as you are potentially putting that patient at risk.

questions:
A 15-year-old boy from Manchester is brought to surgery by his mother complaining of abdominal pains for the past two days. On examination there is a clinical suspicion of appendicitis and a referral to hospital is planned. On discussing this with the patient he refuses to be admitted. He is able to understand all information you give him and repeat it, including the serious nature of untreated appendicitis.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC have produced guidance on making decisions when dealing with patients aged 0-18 years.

They state the following: '31. Parents cannot override the competent consent of a young person to treatment that you consider is in their best interests. But you can rely on parental consent when a child lacks the capacity to consent. In Scotland parents cannot authorise treatment a competent young person has refused. In England,Wales and Northern Ireland, the law on parents overriding young peoples competent refusal is complex. You should seek legal advice if you think treatment is in the best interests of a competent young person who refuses.'

Ideally you should start by exploring why he doesn't want to be admitted (previous bad experience, recent death of a relative in etc). However, if he is still reluctant then the GMC advise seeking legal advice. In reality it is highly unlikely that a child (albeit a 15-year-old) would be allowed to deny himself life-saving treatment.

To avoid forcing treatment on a patient one option would be to not admit him but give him relevant clinic advice.

Option A is unlikely to be effective and will only alienate a young patient. Option D is completely inappropriate.

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on medical nights. On arriving for hand over you are told there are 15 patients waiting to be clerked, including two patients in resus. The medical registrar is stuck on HDU with a poorly patient. The F2 doctor has called in sick.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is unfortunately not an uncommon scenario for junior doctors. Being able to deal appropriately with busy and stressful situations is one of the key requirements of specialist trainees.

The best response is to inform the on-call consultant of the situation. The patients are being admitted under his/her care and should be made aware of potential problems. Whilst in practice many consultants will effectively say 'get on with it' there are a number of consultants who would come in if they felt the situation was dangerous.

The next best option is to prioritise and see the patients with life-threatening conditions. Clerking in all patients to identify the ill ones negates the benefit of the doctor-doctor handover and risks delaying interventions in sick patients.

Using the whole experience to gain experience may be admirable in one respect but does not show any adaptation to the situation at hand.

Asking nurses to perform the duties of a doctor is clearly inappropriate and the worst option.

options: Acknowledge the patient’s feelings and apologise if they felt disrespected
Clarify what was said and ask how the patient interpreted the communication

questions:
A patient becomes upset during a consultation and accuses you of being rude. You were unaware that a gesture you used is offensive in their culture. You feel your communication was respectful but want to handle the situation professionally.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
A: Acknowledge the patient’s feelings and apologise if they felt disrespected
Empathy maintains trust. Good Medical Practice (para. 26): “You must listen to patients, take account of their views and respond honestly and openly.” An apology for the impact, not the intent, is appropriate.

B: Clarify what was said and ask how the patient interpreted the communication
Promotes understanding and aligns with GMC Communication guidance (para. 5): “You should check that patients have understood what you have said and respond to their questions.”

E: Make a note in the medical record about the interaction
Documentation supports continuity and accountability (Good Medical Practice, para. 78).

C: Discuss the situation with a colleague or senior for feedback on your approach
Encouraged for reflective practice (Good Medical Practice, para. 9), but secondary to addressing the patient directly.

D: Ignore it, as you didn’t mean to cause offence
Failing to acknowledge harm undermines trust. Good Medical Practice (para. 25) emphasises maintaining respect and openness, even when misunderstanding occurs.
question:
A patient becomes upset during a consultation and accuses you of being rude. You were unaware that a gesture you used is offensive in their culture. You feel your communication was respectful but want to handle the situation professionally.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
question_notes:
A: Acknowledge the patient’s feelings and apologise if they felt disrespected
Empathy maintains trust. Good Medical Practice (para. 26): “You must listen to patients, take account of their views and respond honestly and openly.” An apology for the impact, not the intent, is appropriate.

B: Clarify what was said and ask how the patient interpreted the communication
Promotes understanding and aligns with GMC Communication guidance (para. 5): “You should check that patients have understood what you have said and respond to their questions.”

E: Make a note in the medical record about the interaction
Documentation supports continuity and accountability (Good Medical Practice, para. 78).

C: Discuss the situation with a colleague or senior for feedback on your approach
Encouraged for reflective practice (Good Medical Practice, para. 9), but secondary to addressing the patient directly.

D: Ignore it, as you didn’t mean to cause offence
Failing to acknowledge harm undermines trust. Good Medical Practice (para. 25) emphasises maintaining respect and openness, even when misunderstanding occurs.
title: GMC: Good medical practice - Communication, partnership and teamwork
body:
Communication, partnership and teamwork form one of the four domains listed in the Good Medical Practice. This domain focuses on the standards expected of doctors in areas such as communication and collaboration with patients and colleagues.

Effective communication
  • Listen to patients and answer any questions honestly
  • Ensure that information is delivered in a manner that can be understood. Identify and apply practical measures to overcome any communication and language barriers
  • Provide support and information to patients' relatives or carers in a considerate manner
  • Doctors on duty need to be easily reachable by their patients and colleagues for any advice or support

Partnership with patients
  • Empower patients with the information required for patients to make decisions with regards to their care. This includes information on the clinical conditions, treatment options and the relevant risks and uncertainties
  • Ensure that patients are aware of the progress of their care
  • The roles and responsibilities of each member of the team need to be made clear to the patients
  • Patient confidentiality needs to be maintained, even after the patient is deceased

Fair and respectful care of all patients
  • Respect patients' dignity and privacy
  • Respect any health, cultural and religious beliefs held by the patients, even if they do not agree with yours.

If you have a conscientious objection to a particular procedure e.g. abortion, you need to:
  • Inform the patient that they have the right to see another practitioner
  • Provide the necessary information and support towards the patient seeking another doctor. In doing so, refrain from expressing disapproval of the patient's lifestyle, choices or beliefs
  • Find another doctor to substitute you if it is not practical for the patient to arrange to see another doctor

Partnership with colleagues
  • Doctors are expected to work in a team in a manner that serves patients' best interest
  • It is important to respect the skills and contributions of every member of the team and be fair to every member of the team
  • Understand that your actions may affect others within and outside the team
  • It is your duty to complete any post that you have formally accepted as leaving the post assigned to you may compromise patient safety especially if this creates a gap in the medical rota
  • Unless the trust has a reasonable time to make adjustments, it is important that you work the hours required of your contract before leaving a job

Coordination of care between healthcare providers and between health and social care providers. This include
  • Providing all relevant information to all clinicians or social care providers involved in the care of the patients
  • Checking that a named doctor or team has taken over the care
  • Ensure that the clinician filling in for you or taking over the care is appropriately trained to provide safe care for the patient

The Good Medical Practice also made statements with regards to Doctors as teachers. It recommends that doctors support the training and teaching of junior staff members and medical students*. This includes
  • Ensuring adequate supervision
  • Writing honest feedback/references/appraisals on their competence, performance and conduct
  • Being a mentor
  • Supporting those who are struggling with their performance or health

*In all circumstances, patient safety needs to be prioritised

questions:
A colleague shows you a popular podcast made by a registrar you work with, who publishes under the pseudonym: Dr Traumatised. In several episodes, they recount anonymous ward stories with striking detail (age, rare diagnoses, shifts, and hospital routines that closely match your trust). In the latest episode, they joke about a patient’s behaviour and mention a distinctive tattoo and profession. The registrar’s bio says views are personal and names are changed. The show is monetised with ads.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Speak to the registrar privately, outline your concerns about potential patient identification and unprofessional content, and ask them to remove the episodes is most appropriate. Your first duty is to protect patients and prevent further harm. GMC guidance on confidentiality and doctors’ use of social media states you must not disclose information that could identify patients—even if names are changed. A discreet, proportionate approach respects the colleague’s dignity, may rapidly contain risk (by removing content), and models professional behaviour.

Review the specific episode(s), note time-stamps and potentially identifying details, and check local social-media/information governance policy to frame a clear concern is most appropriate. Raising concerns should be honest, fair, and evidence-based. Minimal fact-checking (without circulating the content) ensures accuracy and helps you describe the risk precisely to seniors/information governance. This avoids gossip and aligns with GMC expectations around fairness and probity.

Escalate through your line manager/clinical lead or Freedom to Speak Up Guardian) and follow the organisation’s information-governance policy is most appropriate. Potential breaches of confidentiality and professionalism require prompt escalation so the trust can assess risk, involve information governance/legal/comms, and coordinate remedial actions. GMC guidance is clear: act without delay when patient safety or public trust may be at risk, and use formal channels.

The remaining options are inappropriate/less appropriate:

Post a warning in the staff WhatsApp with a link to the podcast so others “see the problem” is inappropriate. Broadcasting/resharing the content amplifies the breach and risks further disclosure. Use official channels and the principle of minimum necessary disclosure.

Leave an anonymous public review on the podcast platform criticising the registrar’s behaviour to pressure them to stop is inappropriate. Public shaming is unprofessional, may prejudice fair investigation, and can worsen disclosure. Concerns should be handled via proper organisational routes.

Do nothing because the registrar uses a pseudonym and says details are changed is inappropriate. A pseudonym does not remove professional duties. If people locally could identify a patient from the details, it’s still a breach. You must act on reasonable concerns. The GMC does not explicitly ban doctors from using pseudonyms, but its guidance on using social media strongly advises against it when discussing health or healthcare matters. The overarching principle is that doctors' online conduct must maintain public trust in the profession.

Ask the student nurse who recognised the patient to check with the patient whether they noticed and obtain retrospective consent is inappropriate. Consent must be informed and prospective; seeking it after publication is coercive and widens the breach. Focus on containment and formal management.

Immediately report the registrar to the GMC is inappropriate. External referral may be necessary for serious/persistent issues, but GMC advises using local mechanisms first unless there’s an urgent, grave, or unmanageable risk. You should escalate externally if these issues are unresolved or very serious.

Complete an incident report per policy about what you have observed online is inappropriate at this stage. Documentation and incident reporting support organisational learning and any duty-of-candour processes if patients were affected. It follows immediate containment and escalation (which are the most appropriate of these options).

Share short clips with non-clinical friends to ask if they can identify the patient is inappropriate. Unnecessary sharing extends the breach and violates confidentiality. Only those who need to know should be involved.

title: GMC: social media
body:
The GMC has produced detailed guidance on the use of social media.

One of the key passages discusses anonymity online:


17. If you identify yourself as a doctor in publicly accessible social media, you should also identify yourself by name. Any material written by authors who represent themselves as doctors is likely to be taken on trust and may reasonably be taken to represent the views of the profession more widely.§

18. You should also be aware that content uploaded anonymously can, in many cases, be traced back to its point of origin.

Please see the link for more details.
